Fig. 1 TEM images of fresh AC (a–c) and g-NC (d–f) catalysts. Fig 1 Fig. 2 TGA and DTG curves of fresh and used Ru/g-NC catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of fresh (a) and used (b) catalysts. Fig 3 Fig. 4 HAADF-STEM images of the fresh Ru/AC (a) and Ru/g-NC (b, c, and d) catalysts. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) Ru 3p 3/2, (b) N 1 s, and (c) C 1 s XPS spectra of the catalysts. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Fourier transforms of k2 -weighted Ru K-edge XANES (a) and EXAFS (b) of Ru samples. Fig 6 Fig. 7 WT-EXAFS of Ru samples. Fig 7 Fig. 8 HCl-TPD (a) and C2H2-TPD (b) curves of fresh Ru-based catalysts. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Acetylene conversion (a) and selectivity to vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) (b) of the catalysts. Laboratory test conditions: GHSV(C2H2), 90 h−1; temperature, 180 °C; reactive gas volume ratio (V C2H2/V HCl), 1: 1.15. Fig 9 Fig. 10 Acetylene conversion and selectivity to VCM on the Ru/g-NC catalyst during long-term running. School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering/ State Key Laboratory Incubation Base for Green Processing of Chemical Engineering Shihezi University Shihezi 832000 PR China Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have sparked gigantic attention due to their high activity, atomic utilization, and unique metal–host coordination environment. A hard-template method with Lewis acid modification strategy was adopted to obtain mesoporous N-doped carbon nanospheres as the host to prepare a Ru SAC for acetylene hydrochlorination. The single site scattered Ru-N-C active structure constructed by the interaction between the metal–support and the heteroatom-rich mesoporous g-NC nanosphere material provides a rich defect structure that promotes the mass transfer of reactants and products. Furthermore, the N-doped support anchors, disperses and modulates the catalytic active domains, stabilizing their active state and enhancing the adsorption and activation of initial reactants. As a result, the obtained Ru SAC possesses excellent catalytic properties and lasting life in a 500-h test, which render it highly promising for industrial applications. Moreover, the clarified catalytic mechanism provides a reference for the preparation of other SACs. Graphical abstract Efficient acetylene hydrochlorination:The single-site-dispersed Ru-N-C local active centers facilitate the mass transfer of reactants and products, modulate the electronic properties of the metal centers, stabilizing their active state and improving the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ru single-atom catalysts N-doped carbon materials Strong metal–support interaction Ru–N–C active domain Acetylene hydrochlorination Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The increasing demand for polyvinyl chloride (PVC) products in various industries [1–4], has given a new impetus to the key technology of PVC production, namely, the hydrochlorination reaction of acetylene for the synthesis of vinyl chloride monomer (VCM). However, existing processes still rely on highly toxic and volatile mercury-based catalysts, which will be banned by 2025 [5]. To ensure the green transformation and upgrading development of the PVC industry, the design and development of alternative catalysts is a pressing concern. Previous studies for acetylene hydrochlorination reaction have shown that although nonnoble metal and nonmetallic catalysts have good selectivity to VCM, their catalytic activity still needs further improvement [6–10]. With regard to noble metals, gold (Au)-based catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic activity and selectivity to VCM [11]; however, despite having excellent initial activity, the deactivation of Au-based catalysts is mainly caused by the reduction and agglomeration of active metal sites [12–14]. To further improve their stability, a series of methods have been adopted, such as the use of organic ligands containing soft donor atoms (for example, sulfur-containing ligands to stabilize cationic Au) [11,13], ionic liquids [15], additional metals [9,15–21], and functionalized carriers [22]. Some of these approaches have even reached pilot plant evaluation [11,13]; for example, Na3Au(S2O3)2 was selected as the metal precursor of the catalyst to possess good catalytic properties, with 1 kg of catalyst producing 1000 kg of VCM. Needless to say, Au-based catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic performance. Nevertheless, although the catalytic performance is essential from the viewpoint of actual industrial production, the cost of the catalyst also needs to be considered. Since the high cost of Au-based catalysts limits their practical application, researchers are turning their attention to other noble metals with relatively low prices, such as platinum (Pt) and ruthenium (Ru) [23–25]. Among them, Ru-based catalysts have catalytic activity almost equivalent to Au-based catalysts [24]. For example, our previous work has demonstrated that the acetylene (C2H2) conversion of Ru1Co(III)3/SAC (SAC: spherical activated carbon) remains above 95% after 48 h of continuous reaction at temperature of 170℃ and C2H2 gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 180 h−1 [26]. However, the introduction of auxiliary metals also brings negative effects such as low selectivity, which may lead to coke deposition and rapid deactivation of the catalyst [27]. Not long ago, the research group of Pérez-Ramírez reported that when Ru nanoparticles (particle size: 1.5 nm) were loaded on N-modified carbon materials, the catalyst exhibited excellent activity, and proved that catalyst deactivation was due to the coking caused by carbon deposition, which masked the active sites. Very creatively, they prevented metal redispersion by encapsulating Ru NPs into a monolayer graphene shell and introduced O2 during the reaction to limit coke formation [28]. Immediately afterwards, we designed an efficient Ru-based catalyst (1Ru-5IL5/AC) using an ionic liquid (IL) as a promoter, achieving an excellent C2H2 conversion (99.51%) at temperature of 170 °C and GHSV (C2H2) of 180 h−1. In the presence of IL auxiliaries, the dispersity of the active species increased from 26.90% for Ru/AC to an atomic-level dispersion of 54.26% for 1Ru-5IL5/AC [29]. However, Ru catalysts are inevitably deactivated due to the reduction of metal cations by C2H2 and coke deposition caused by oligomerization of C2H2 or VCM during the reaction, which are problems that require immediate solution. SACs have recently attracted intense attention due to their high activity, high selectivity, atomic utilization, and unique metal–host coordination environment [30–32]. However, it is still unclear whether Ru NPs with a certain size (such as 1.5 nm) or single-site-dispersed Ru species are more favorable for the catalytic reaction of C2H2 and HCl. Conductive polymer materials have been extensively applied in the field of catalysis due to their conjugated electronic structure, good electrical conductivity, and stability. For instance, the main chain of polyaniline contains alternating N atoms and benzene rings, has excellent environmental stability and electrical conductivity, and can be used as a template compound of carbon and nitrogen. Thus, mesoporous carbon materials rich in pyridine N can be generated after carbonization of polyaniline at high temperature using silica colloidal NPs as a porous induction template. In this work, to investigate the role of SACs in the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction, a hard-template method with Lewis acid modification strategy was adopted to obtain mesoporous N-doped partially graphitized carbon matrix nanospheres as the host for preparing a Ru SAC. We envisaged that N atoms uniformly distributed in the matrix would serve as both Lewis bases and anchoring sites for Lewis acidic Run+ to form an Ru–N–C active domain [33] and a mesoporous foam structure of N-doped carbon nanospheres would facilitate the mass transfer of reactants during the catalysis process [34,35]. A combination of various characterization techniques and molecular simulation calculations revealed the catalytic reaction behavior and mechanism of the Ru–N–C SAC. This work can be expected to give a theoretical basis as well as technical support for the design and development of catalysts with industrial application. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Granular active carbon (coconut, 30–70 mesh) was provided by S. S. Activated Carbon Co., Ltd. Ludox AM-40 silica colloid solution and RuCl3⋅3H2O were procured from Sigma Aldrich. Ammonium persulfate (APS) was procured from Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. aniline, hydrochloric acid (37 wt.%), ammonia water (25–28 wt.%), N, N-Dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.5 wt.%), sodium hydroxide, nitromethane, and ethanol were procured from Sigma Aldrich. All the chemicals needed for the experiment do not require further purification and can be used directly in the experiment. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Mesoporous N-doped partially graphitized carbon matrix nanospheres (g-NC) were prepared by the following procedures: 1 mL of aniline solution was dissolved in deionized water containing 1.6 g of silica solution, followed by addition of 1.2 mol L−1 hydrochloric acid solution to regulate its pH to 3 and sonication for 1 h. Subsequently, 0.6 mol L−1 aqueous APS solution was introduced, and the above solution was sonicated again for 1 h, and then placed at 25 °C for 18 h. After centrifugation, washing with ethanol and deionized water for three times, and centrifugation, 1 mol L−1 ammonia water was introduced and then the above solution was placed at room temperature for 18 h, centrifuged, washed with deionized water three times, and centrifuged again. Then, the sample was dried in a blast air oven at 80 °C for 12 h, calcined under N2 atmosphere at 800 °C for 3 h, and then placed in a mixed solution of ethanol and sodium hydroxide (volume ratio of 1:1, 500 mL), stirred for 6 h, centrifuged, and washed three times with anhydrous ethanol and deionized water. At last, continuous drying at 80 °C for another 12 h produced the carrier, which was labeled as g-NC. The isolated Ru-based SAC was synthesized by the following procedures: 4.5 g of g-NC and 10 mL of aniline solution were dissolved in nitromethane solution, and 0.2983 g of RuCl3·3H2O precursor was introduced. The above solution was stirred for 6 h, placed at 25 °C for 12 h, and washed with nitromethane solution three times after centrifugation. The obtained material was placed at 80 °C for another 12 h and then calcined in a tube furnace under N2 atmosphere at 800 °C for 3 h. The sample was poured into a mixed solution of ethanol and sodium hydroxide (volume ratio of 1:1, 500 mL) for 6 h and then placed at 25 °C for 12 h, centrifuged, washed with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol solution, and dried at 80 °C for another 12 h to afford the Ru SAC, which was labeled as Ru/g-NC. Treated activated carbon (AC) was prepared as follows: The original activated carbon (4.5 g) was introduced into nitromethane solution (400 mL), impregnated and stirred for 24 h, filtered, washed with methanol and DMF solution for three times, and then vacuum dried at 120 °C for 24 h. Finally, calcination in a furnace under N2 atmosphere at 800 °C for 3 h produced the AC sample. Ru/AC was synthesized according to the following impregnation method: 0.2983 g of RuCl3⋅3H2O precursor was dissolved in nitromethane solution (400 mL), followed by addition of AC (4.5 g), impregnation, and stirring for a whole day. The sample was filtered, washed with methanol and DMF for three times, and then vacuum dried at 120 °C for 24 h. After calcination in a furnace under N2 atmosphere at 800 °C for 3 h, Ru/AC was obtained. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation, catalyst characterizations, and research on catalysis mechanism The catalytic evaluation, catalyst characterizations, and the research on catalysis mechanism by simulation calculations can be found in Supporting Information file. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of the catalyst structural properties on the reaction system The morphology of the prepared carbon materials was visually analyzed by TEM. In the high-magnification TEM images shown in Fig. 1 , local graphitization of the AC and g-NC catalysts can be observed (Fig. 1a and 1d). Notably, compared with AC (Fig. 1b and 1c), the synthesized g-NC material is mainly composed of mesoporous carbon matrix randomly crosslinked by N-doped monolayer mesoporous carbon nanospheres (Fig. 1e and 1f). To further explore the physical structure parameters of the catalysts, a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis was performed. As shown in Fig. S1, the low-temperature N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of fresh and spent AC and Ru/AC catalysts are type-I curves, indicating that the prepared catalysts are rich in micropores. The structural parameters listed in Table 1 show that the BET specific surface area (S BET) and total pore volume (V P) of unused AC samples are larger than those of unused Ru/AC samples, which is due to the fact that the Ru species occupy part of the pores of the carrier. The synthesized g-NC material also has considerable S BET and V P values. However, its type-IV adsorption–desorption isotherms, significantly increase average pore diameter (15.13 nm), and the pore size distribution (Fig. S2) demonstrates the mesoporous property of the material. Unexpectedly, the specific surface area of the fresh Ru/g-CN catalyst increases after the Ru precursor is loaded on the support, which indicates that the Ru component is located on the support surface and interacts with heteroatoms in the support to form a new foam-like defect structure. Moreover, even after the introduction of Ru, the Ru/g-NC catalyst still exhibits a very rich mesoporous structure (Table 1, Figs. S1 and S2). In addition, the reacted samples show different degrees of S BET and V P loss due to the formation of carbonaceous byproducts or pore collapse caused by high temperature during the reaction, with ΔS BET and ΔV P values decreasing in the order AC > g-NC > Ru/AC > Ru/g-NC. Further evaluation of the anticoking performance of the Ru catalyst was performed by subjecting the fresh and used Ru/g-NC samples to TGA (Fig. 2 ). According to the literature [29], the catalyst mainly undergoes three stages of weightlessness: 〈 100 °C, 100 °C–500 °C, and 〉 500 °C, which can be explained as moisture desorption from the surface of sample, the combustion of carbonaceous by-product, and the burning of the carbon carrier substrate, respectively. Therefore, the catalyst's weight loss difference between the used catalyst and the fresh catalyst in 100–500℃ is generally regarded as the carbonaceous byproduct deposition amount during the catalytic reaction process. Serious carbonaceous byproduct deposition occurs on AC (10.42%) and the AC-supported Ru catalyst (1.20%) (Fig. S3 and Table 2 ), which will eventually cover the active site and inhibit mass transfer of reactant molecules (C2H2 and HCl) and product (VCM) molecules, leading to a rapid decline in Ru/AC catalyst activity. Modification with the g-NC support significantly decreases the coking deposition on the Ru/g-NC (0.24%) catalyst surface (Fig. 2 and Table 2). This can be attributed to the SMSI and the ordered mesoporous structure of the material, which are beneficial for the electrophilic addition reaction and the mass transfer of HCl and C2H2, thus reducing the ΔS BET and ΔV P of the catalyst and further allowing the long-lasting exposure of Ru active sites and the outstanding sustained catalytic performance. 3.2 Dispersibility and crystal phase of Ru components in the catalysts The prepared carrier plays a very important role in the anchoring and dispersion of Ru components, which was investigated by using Raman, XRD, HAADF-STEM, and ICP-OES techniques in this work. Except the amorphous diffraction peaks of activated carbon (2θ = 23.22°, 43.79° and 79.58°), no characteristic Ru reflections are distinguished in the diffraction patterns of the fresh and used catalysts (Fig. 3 ). This can be due to any of the following situations: the Ru-containing species are not loaded on the support, are present as amorphous Ruz+ (z > 0) species, or are uniformly scattered in the catalyst with a size below the XRD detection limit (4 nm). However, the ICP-OES result reveals an Ru species amount close to 0.5 wt.% in the fresh catalysts, indicating that the Ru species has been successfully loaded onto the support (Table S1). The slightly higher Ru loading in the Ru/g-NC catalyst illustrates the better anchoring of Ru-containing species by heteroatoms in the support. In addition, the g-NC and Ru/g-NC peaks at 43.79° are much weaker than those of AC and Ru/AC (Fig. 3), indicating a decrease in the degree of graphitization from AC to g-NC materials. Moreover, the increase in the ID/IG value from 1.06 for AC to 1.08 for g-NC (Fig. S4) demonstrates that defect sites are more abundant in g-NC, which is beneficial for anchoring the metal components that serve as the active sites for the reaction. This is further verified by means of an HAADF-STEM analysis. Fig. 4 a indicates that except for a modicum of isolated Ru single sites, a substantial amount of Ru clusters is distinguished in the Ru/AC catalyst. Functional carrier g-NC successfully causes the ruthenium species to disperse at the level of single atom in Ru/g-NC catalyst (Fig. 4b). Especially, the Ru single atoms are mainly evenly distributed on the outer wall of the channels (Fig. 4 and 4d). 3.3 Internal relationship between electronic properties and coordination structures An XPS analysis was conducted to explore the influence of the electronic features of the active centers on the acetylene hydrochlorination system. As evident from Fig. 5 a and Table S2, the XPS spectra suggest that four types of peaks at binding energies (BEs) of nearby 461.3 eV (Ru0 species), 463.5 (Ru3+ species), 465.0 (Ru4+ species), and 467.1 eV (Run+ species; n > 4) are derived from the Ru 3p 3/2 spectrum of Ru/AC catalyst. By comparison, the obvious BE shift for various Ru-containing components to the high energy direction in the spectrum of the unreacted Ru/g-NC suggests the interplay between the g-NC carrier and Ru precursor, which can obviously optimize the electronic microenvironment of the central metal atom. Moreover, the percentage of RuP+ (P ≥ 4) species in the Ru/g-NC catalyst increases obviously after loading the Ru precursors on the g-NC material. This may be due to the coordination between N in g-NC and Ru components, which keeps Ru components in a stable active state. Concurrently, the deconvolution and fitting of the N 1 s XPS spectra (Fig. 5b) reveal that four kinds of N components with peaks at BEs of ca. 403.0 eV (oxidized-N species), 400.9 eV (graphitic-N species), 400.1 eV (pyrrolic-N species), and 399.7 eV (pyridinic-N species), are observed for the Ru/AC catalyst [36]. In contrast, the appearance of a peak at a BE of 399.0 eV belonging to Ru–N components in the spectrum of the Ru/g-NC catalyst indicates that the strong interaction between g-NC support and Ru components is mainly due to the coordination between N in g-NC and Ru components [36]. Additionally, the N 1 s and C 1 s spectra of the Ru/g-NC catalyst slightly shift to lower energy and higher energy, respectively, compared with those of g-NC (Fig. 5b and 5c), which indicates that electrons are transferred from the adjacent C atom to the Ru-N sites, stabilizing the active metal centers [36]. This fine-tuning of the electronic properties without changing the dispersion of single atoms is very important for SACs because it can decouple the catalytic activity and chemoselectivity under certain conditions [37]. To be specific, the stress alteration in the curved carbon shell causes the graphene layer to deviate from the plane, which allows the transfer of π-electrons from the inner surface (concave) to the outer surface (convex), correspondingly leading to electron-rich states and electron-deficient outside and inside, respectively [38]. Considering that photoreduction of ruthenium species may occur at the high energies of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, an XAS characterization experiment was performed to gain more insight into the valence state and coordination environment of Ru active components. Compared with RuCl3 standard, the benchmark Ru/AC catalyst exhibits similar absorption edges and white line peak intensities (Fig. 6 a), while those of the Ru/g-NC catalyst are found to resemble those of the RuO2 standard. This indicates that the mean oxidation state of the active metal components in Ru/g-NC catalysts is in the range of 3+∼ 4+, which is caused by the coordination of N atoms on the support with Ru precursors and is consistent with the XPS results [39]. Additionally, obvious Ru–Ru (2.68 Å), Ru–O (1.99 Å), and Ru–Cl (2.34 Å) features are observed in the EXAFS of the control samples, i.e., Ru foil, RuCl3, and RuO2, respectively. Apart from the Ru–O/N and Ru–Cl characteristics produced by the coordination between metal components and O/N-containing groups on the AC support, plentiful Ru–Ru components are clearly sorted out in the spectrum of the benchmark catalyst, indicating that the Ru components are self-agglomerated in the benchmark catalyst (Figs. 6b, 7 , S5 and Table S3). By comparison, the successful introduction of ruthenium components onto g-NC carrier results in the construction of a local Ru–N structure (since there is no O atom in polyaniline, the peak is considered as the characteristic of Ru–N bond), as well as the absence of the Ru-Ru bond in the resultant catalyst Ru/g-NC. These results suggest the strong interaction between the heteroatomic N structure in g-NC and the Ru active species. Moreover, the structural force and steric effect of the constructed Ru-N structure contribute to the dispersion of single Ru sites, as was confirmed by the HAADF-STEM results (Fig. 6b–d). 3.4 Adsorption of the reactants by the active sites in the catalyst In catalytic reactions, the adsorption and activation of the initial reactants by the active sites plays an important role in the catalytic performance of the catalysts. The surface of carbon carrier contains abundant N or O groups, which have high electronegativity and tend to attack H atom in HCl molecule, thus activating HCl bond and resulting in HCl desorption peak of g-NC and AC bare carrier at ca. 168℃ (Fig. 8 a). Notably, the introduction of Ru species triggers the multistate adsorption of the catalyst to the initial reactants at 168 °C and 335 °C because the electron cloud density altered by electronic microenvironment around Ru is closely bound up with the adsorption/activation of HCl molecules. The g-NC material is rich in highly active primary and secondary amines, which can generate hydrogen-bond interaction with H atom in the HCl molecule [40,41]. Furthermore, the stable Ru–N–C active domain formed in the catalyst allows electrons to be transferred from the adjacent C atom to the Ru-N sites through the bridging effect of the Ru–N–C bond, as illustrated in the XPS analysis, thereby stabilizing the metal active centers and greatly increasing the adsorption performance of the Ru/g-NC catalyst for initial HCl [22,42,43]. Moreover, the sufficient π-electron system and the d orbitals of Run+ components allow AC support and Ru catalysts to exhibit adsorption and activation ability for small molecules like the C2H2 reactant by π–π interactions. Simultaneously, the sufficient π-electron system of the aromatic rings in the polyaniline-derived g-NC material also contributes to and the adsorption/activation of C2H2 molecules. Notably, the N-containing groups can construct a locally active Ru–N–C domain with Ru, promoting the adsorption/activation of initial reactant molecules (Fig. 8b). In a word, the generation of a single-site-dispersed Ru–N–C locally active structure via the interaction between Ru and the g-NC material can improve the adsorption performance of catalyst for initial reactants, further augmenting the activity of acetylene hydrochlorination catalyst. 3.5 Catalytic activity of catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination reaction and long-term stability of the Ru SAC According to the above characterization analysis, the local active centers of single-site-dispersed Ru–N–C constructed via strong interactions between the metal–support and the heteroatom-rich mesoporous g-NC nanosphere material can not only form a rich defect structure, improving the specific surface area to promote the mass transfer of reactants and products and the carbon deposition resistance, but also anchor and disperse the catalytic active domains and optimize the electronic microenvironment of the metal center, stabilizing its active state and facilitating the catalysts to adsorb and activate the reactant molecules. In principle, this is beneficial to the catalytic electrophilic addition reaction of C2H2 and HCl. To verify this conjecture, the catalysts were evaluated for the reaction of acetylene hydrochlorination (Fig. 9 ). As can be extracted from Fig. 9a, bare AC has a low catalytic activity, with the C2H2 conversion dropping to 10% shortly after the beginning of the reaction. In comparison, the catalytic activity of the N-doped mesoporous carbon nanosphere g-NC material increases significantly, reaching a C2H2 conversion of 59% after reacting for 50 h. After the loading of Ru precursors, the C2H2 conversion reaches 93% with good initial activity over the Ru/AC catalyst. However, after 50 h of continuous operation, the C2H2 conversion decreases to 83%, which is indicative of the relatively inferior stability of the catalyst. By contrast, the strong metal–support interaction dramatically augments the catalytic activity of Ru/g-NC catalyst, with the highest C2H2 conversion, a TOF value, and a deactivation rate of 98.05%, 256.74 h−1, and only 1.5% during the catalytic evaluation. Therefore, the constructed single-site-dispersed Ru–N–C can be considered the most active species in view of the catalytic activity sequence (Ru/g-NC > Ru/AC > g-NC > AC) and the excellent selectivity to VCM, which is higher than 99% (Fig. 9b), and the Ru catalyst supported on the heteroatom-rich mesoporous g-NC nanosphere material is also proven to be a promising material for acetylene hydrochlorination. To investigate the large-scale industrial applicability of the Ru/g-NC catalyst, a long-term stability test was performed at a GHSV twice that of the real industrial production. An initial C2H2 conversion of 99.67% is achieved, and no significant decrease is observed after 500 h of on-stream reaction over the Ru/g-NC catalyst. This result, together with the excellent and stable selectivity toward VCM, renders the environmentally friendly catalyst Ru/g-NC highly promising for the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction (Fig. 10 ). 3.6 Study on the mechanism of catalytic reaction The mechanism of the acetylene hydrochlorination catalyzed by the Ru SAC was investigated by means of DFT calculations (Figs. 11–13 ). Considering that Ru species in Ru/g-NC catalysts are basically Ru-N coordination bonds (Fig. 6), the stable Ru–N6 structure M1 was acquired through optimization and adopted as the model (Fig. 12). When the reaction starts, the initial M1 captures C2H2 and HCl molecules to successively form the coadsorption states M2 and M3. Then, an HCl molecule attacks the Ru-N-C active domain, resulting in the cleavage of the Ru-N bond in the active domain and thus leaving an active site to accommodate reactant molecule; in the M1 model, the Ru center absorbs the Cl atom in the HCl molecule. Meanwhile, the N structure in M1 captures the H atom in the HCl molecule, and through the cooperative interaction between N and Ru in the Ru-N structure, the M-TS1 transition state is generated by activating the HCl bond. Subsequently, M4 is produced in response to the capture of a C2H2 molecule, and M5 is then generated through the M-TS2 transition state. This is regarded as the rate-limiting step of the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction, with an associated reaction energy barrier of −7.58 kcal mol−1. Eventually, the VCM molecule is disconnected from M5 to produce the VCM product and the initial M1, closing the catalytic cycle (Fig. 12). The length of the Ru-N bonds in the original model was also calculated (Fig. 13), and the result is consistent with that of the XAS analysis. 4 Conclusions To sum up, benefiting from the numerous N-containing functional groups of a polyaniline-derived g-NC material, an Ru SAC supported by mesoporous carbon nanospheres was prepared. During the catalyst synthesis, the strong metal–support interaction can modulate the coordination environment of the Ru atoms to establish a Ru–N–C active domain based on Ru single atomic site. This affords a rich defect structure that increases the chance of contact between reactants and active species. Furthermore, it induces the stable anchoring and high dispersion of more active Ru components. In addition, the constructed Ru–N–C active structure facilitates the adsorption/activation of reactant molecules, improving catalytic performance and the resistance to coking deposition. As a result, the most active catalyst (Ru/g-NC) can achieve a C2H2 conversion of 96.56%, which is significantly superior to the Ru/AC benchmark catalyst (82.68%) during a 50-h test. The ultra-high stability of the Ru/g-NC catalyst, which exhibits only a 1.5% deactivation rate during a 500-h test at a GHSV twice that of real industrial production, demonstrates its potential for industrial applications. Therefore, the design strategy and the clarification of the catalytic mechanism by DFT simulation presented in this work offer new insights to improve the catalytic activity of Ru catalysts and the utilization rate of noble metal atoms, which has far-reaching implications for the green and sustainable development of VCM synthesis catalyzed by economical Ru catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have sparked gigantic attention due to their high activity, atomic utilization, and unique metal–host coordination environment. A hard-template method with Lewis acid modification strategy was adopted to obtain mesoporous N-doped carbon nanospheres as the host to prepare a Ru SAC for acetylene hydrochlorination. The single site scattered Ru-N-C active structure constructed by the interaction between the metal–support and the heteroatom-rich mesoporous g-NC nanosphere material provides a rich defect structure that promotes the mass transfer of reactants and products. Furthermore, the N-doped support anchors, disperses and modulates the catalytic active domains, stabilizing their active state and enhancing the adsorption and activation of initial reactants. As a result, the obtained Ru SAC possesses excellent catalytic properties and lasting life in a 500-h test, which render it highly promising for industrial applications. Moreover, the clarified catalytic mechanism provides a reference for the preparation of other SACs.
coredata.dc:title: Construction of Ru single-atom catalyst with abundant Ru-N active domains for highly efficient acetylene hydrochlorination
